facts.text: Appeal is C.A. 556 of 1967 by special leave from judgment and decree dated August 29, 1966 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 644 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. 556 of 1967. Appeal by Special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 29, 1966 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 644 of 1962.

facts.text: Defendants 2 to 7 in the suit are the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Vasudev Pillai and P. Kesava Pillai, for the appellants. R. Chaudhuri and K. Rajendra Chowdhary, for respondents Nos. 1 to 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J. This is an appeal by special leave. Defendants 2 to 7 in the suit are the appellants in this appeal.

facts.text: Plaintiffs (respondents 1 to 4) sued for declaration that Survey Nos. 12 to 18 comprising 10 acres 54 cents in South Vallur village of Vijayawada Taluk are communal lands with villagers' rights of irrigation and drainage.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs who are respondents 1 to 4 herein sued for a declaration that Survey Nos. 12 to 18 companyprising an extent of 10 acres 54 cents in South Vallur village of Vijayawada Taluk are companymunal lands, the villagers therein having rights of irrigation and drainage.

facts.text: Plaintiffs challenged assignment of suit lands to 2nd defendant (1st appellant) by Estates Manager order dated December 21, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In that suit they challenged the assignment of suit lands in favour of the 2nd defendant  1st appellant  by the Estates Manager by his order of December, 21, 1952.

facts.text: Plaintiffs sought permanent injunction restraining defendants from interfering with exercise of rights in suit lands.

anchor.surface_text: They also sought a permanent injunction restraining the defendants from interfering with the exercise of their rights in those lands.

facts.text: Plaintiffs prayed for mandatory injunction against defendants 2 to 7 to restore Agakodu to original condition.

anchor.surface_text: Further they prayed for a mandatory injunction against defendants 2 to 7 directing them to restore Agakodu at their own companyt to its original companydition.

facts.text: Plaintiffs brought suit in representative capacity after obtaining court permission.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs brought the suit in a representative capacity after obtaining the permission of the companyrt.

facts.text: 2nd defendant pleaded possession of Survey Nos. 12 to 15 since 1946 after grant from Zamindar under Patta Ex. B-8 dated January 15, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd defendant resisted the suit on various grounds. He pleaded that he had been in possession of Survey Nos. 12 to 15 ever since 1946, after obtaining a grant from the Zamindar of the ,South Vallur under Patta Ex. B-8 dated January 15, 1946.

facts.text: After abolition of Estates under Estates Abolition Act 1948, Survey Nos. 16 to 18 held unnecessary for original purpose by Collector and granted to 2nd defendant by Estates Manager under Exh. B-16.

anchor.surface_text: According to him after the abolition of the Estates under the Estates Abolition Act, 1948  in short the Estates Abolition Act , Survey Nos. 16 to 18 were held to be unnecessary for the original purpose by the Collector. Thereafter those Survey Nos. were granted to him by the Estates Manager under Exh.B-16.

facts.text: During pendency of suit, Patta for suit lands granted to 2nd defendant under S.11 of Estates Abolition Act by Assistant Settlement Officer under Exh. B-30 dated December 10, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: He further pleaded that during the pendency of the suit, a Patta for the suit lands was granted to him under S. 1 1 of the Estates Abolition Act by the Assistant Settlement Officer under Exh. B-30 dated December 10, 1955.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed plaintiffs' suit, upholding contentions of 2nd defendant, finding plaintiffs failed to establish communal character and lands ceased to be communal due to authorities' orders.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the plaintiffs suit upholding the companytentions of the 2nd defendant. It came to the companyclusion that the plaintiffs had failed to establish the companymunal character of the lands pleaded by them and further even if those lands were companymunal lands at one time, they had ceased to be such in view of the various orders passed by the authorities.

facts.text: First appellate court reversed trial court, decreed plaintiffs' suit, found lands communal with villagers' rights, and defendants' orders invalid or ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellate companyrt reversed the findings of the trial companyrt and decreed the plaintiffs suit as prayed for. It came to the companyclusion that the lands in question were companymunal lands and the villagers had rights of irrigation and drainage through those lands. It further came to the companyclusion that the various orders referred to by the 2nd defendant in his written statement were either invalid or ineffective.

facts.text: High Court affirmed first appellate court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has affirmed the decision of the 1st appellate companyrt.

facts.text: Lands Survey Nos. 12 to 18 measuring 10 acres 54 cents in South Vallur village Vijayawada taluk are poramboke lands, used for irrigation and drainage - not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment of the High Court, it is clear that the arguments in that companyrt proceeded on the basis that the suit lands were once companymunal lands Survey Nos. 12 to 15 even number companytinue to be companymunal lands but Survey Nos. 16 to 18 ceased to be as such because of the order passed by the Collector, Krishna on October 29, 1946 under s. 20-A 1  of the Madras Estates Land Act as well as that passed by the Estates Officer and Assistant Settlement Officer subsequently, to which we shall refer presently. In the companyrse of the judgment the learned judge of the High Court observed It is number in dispute that the lands S. Nos. 12 to 18 and measuring 10 acres and 54 cents, situate in South Vallur village in Vijayawada taluk are poramboke lands.

facts.text: Collector Krishna passed order under Section 20-A(1)(a) Madras Estates Land Act (Ex. A-1) that S. Nos. 16,17,18 no longer required for original purpose.

anchor.surface_text: That they were used for the purpose of irrigation and drainage is also number in dispute. It is companymon ground that under Ex. A-1, the Collector, Krishna passed an order under Section 20-A  I   a  of the Madras Estates Land Act as amended by Madras Act VIII of 1934 to the effect that lands, S. Nos. 16, 17 and 18 were numberlonger required for the purpose for which they were originally intended.

facts.text: Collector order (Ex. A-1) requested Zamindar to state if he had reversionary rights in S. Nos. 16-18.

anchor.surface_text: Under that order, the Collector asked the Zamindar to say whether he had got any reversionary rights in the, lands. What happened subsequently is number clear from the record.

facts.text: No order under section 20-A(2) passed converting S. Nos. 12-15 to ryotwari or assigned till estate abolished; they continued communal.

anchor.surface_text: It is however companymon ground that S. Nos. 12 to 15  both inclusive  companytinued to be companymunal lands and numberorder under section 20-A  2  was at any time passed by Collector companyverting these companymunal lands into, ryotwari lands or assigned them to anyone till the estate was abolished.

facts.text: Appellants conceded before High Court that suit lands were once communal; S.Nos.12-15 continue communal; controversy on 16-18 only.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the stand taken by the appellants before the High Court, it is number permissible for them to companytend that Survey Nos. 12 to 18 were at numbertime companymunal lands number is it open to them to companytend that Survey Nos. 12 to 15 do number still companytinue to be companymunal lands. The companytroversy as regards the nature, of the lands, therefore, must be companyfined to Survey Nos. 16, 17 and 18.

facts.text: Collector's order Ex. A-1 dated around October 1946 only declared S.Nos.16-18 no longer required; no order under cl.b of s.20-A(1).

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Collector on which the first appellant has relied is an incomplete order. Apart from making a declaration that Survey Nos. 16 to 18 are numbermore required for purposes for which they were originally intended, the Collector did number appear to have made any order under cl.  b  of s. 20-A.

facts.text: Estates Manager order dated December 21, 1952 (Ex. B-2) assumed Collector's order converted lands to ryotwari; granted to 1st appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was next placed by the appellants on the order of the Estates Manager dated December 21, 1952  Ex. B-2  for claiming title to the suit properties. In this order the Estates Manager preceded on the basis that the Collectors order to which we have already made reference had already companyverted Survey Nos. 16 to 18 into ryotwari lands.

facts.text: Assistant Settlement Officer order Ex. B-30 dated December 10, 1955 granted ryotwari patta for S.Nos.16-18 to 1st appellant under s.11 Estates Abolition Act during suit pendency without notice to plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly appellants sought support from the order of the Assistant Settlement Officer made on December 10, 1955  Ex. B-30 . This order was made during the pendency of the suit and without numberice to the plaintiffs-respondents. it is purported to have been made under s. 11  a  of the Estates Abolition Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held suit lands continue to be communal lands; appellants have no title.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to accept the companytention of the appellants that Survey Nos. 16 to 18 have ceased to be companymunal lands or that the appellants had obtained any lawful title to them.

facts.text: Estates Abolition Act 1948 abolished estates.

anchor.surface_text: after the abolition of the Estates under the Estates Abolition Act, 1948  in short the Estates Abolition Act ,

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 a  of the Estates Abolition Act, repeals several acts including the Madras Estates Land Act, 1908. In view of cl.  b  of that section all Estates including the communal lands, porambokes and other ryoti lands, waste lands, pasture lands, lanka lands, forests, mines and minerals, quarries, rivers and streams, tanks and irrigation works fisheries and ferries stood transferred to the Government

concepts.interpretation: Vests estates including communal lands in Government free from encumbrances but does not abrogate pre-existing communal rights not created by landholder.

concepts.interpretation: Finality applies only to disputes specified in sub-s.(1): rent arrears, lawful ryot; does not cover whether lands are communal.

concepts.interpretation: Excludes lands set apart for common use of villagers (communal lands) from ryoti land.

anchor.surface_text: So far as Survey Nos. 16 to 18 are concerned, it was said that these lands had ceased to be communal lands as a result of the various orders passed by the authorities. Let us examine whether this contention is correct ?

(1), no land which is set apart ... shall be assigned or used for any other purpose.

The lands with which we are concerned are not lanka lands nor were they declared to be ryoti lands either under the Abolition Act or under the Estates Land Act.

arguments.claim: s.3 EAA vests lands in Government but does not abrogate pre-existing communal rights not created by landholder

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 a  of the Estates Abolition Act, repeals several acts including the Madras Estates Land Act, 1908. In view of cl.  b  of that section all Estates including the communal lands, porambokes and other ryoti lands, waste lands, pasture lands, lanka lands, forests, mines and minerals, quarries, rivers and streams, tanks and irrigation works fisheries and ferries stood transferred to the Government

arguments.claim: Ryoti land under s.3(16) MELA excludes lands set apart for common use of villagers i.e. communal lands

anchor.surface_text: Ryoti land is defined in s. 3  16  which says Ryoti land means cultivable land in an estate other than private land but does not include-  a   b  throshing-floor, cattle-stands, village sites, and other lands situated in any estate which are set apart for the common use of the villagers.

holdings.text: The first contention of Mr. Pillai fails so far as Survey Nos. 12 to 15 are concerned.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the first contention of Mr. Pillai fails so far as Survey Nos. 12 to 15 are concerned. So far as Survey Nos. 16 to 18 are concerned, it was said that these lands had ceased to be communal lands as a result of the various orders passed by the authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants conceded before High Court that suit lands were once communal and S.Nos.12-15 continue communal; cannot reopen conceded facts.

holdings.text: The order of the Collector on which the first appellant has relied is an incomplete order. Apart from making a declaration that Survey Nos. 16 to 18 are no more required for purposes for which they were originally intended, the Collector did not appear to have made any order under cl. b of s. 20-A. Hence despite the order of the Collector, Survey Nos. 16 to 18 continue to be communal lands.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Collector on which the first appellant has relied is an incomplete order. Apart from making a declaration that Survey Nos. 16 to 18 are no more required for purposes for which they were originally intended, the Collector did not appear to have made any order under cl. b of s. 20-A. Hence despite the order of the Collector, Survey Nos. 16 to 18 continue to be communal lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.20-A MELA requires declaration under (1)(a) AND written order under (1)(b) for conversion or assignment; only (1)(a) declaration made; s.(2) prohibits use/assignment without (b) order.

holdings.text: The Estates Manager is not shown to have had any power under any law to convert the communal lands into ryoti lands. Hence his order cannot be considered as having validly converted the suit lands into ryoti lands.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was next placed by the appellants on the order of the Estates Manager dated December 21, 1952 Ex. B-2 for claiming title to the suit properties. In this order the Estates Manager preceded on the basis that the Collectors order to which we have already made reference had already converted Survey Nos. 16 to 18 into ryotwari lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Erroneous assumption that Collector's order converted lands; no legal power to convert communal to ryoti lands.

holdings.text: Section 11 of the Estates Abolition Act, does not authorise the Assistant Settlement Officer to convert the communal land into a ryoti land. ... The lands with which we are concerned are not lanka lands nor were they declared to be ryoti lands either under the Abolition Act or under the Estates Land Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 of the Estates Abolition Act, does not authorise the Assistant Settlement Officer to convert the communal land into a ryoti land. That section reads Every ryot in an estate shall, with effect on and from the notified date, be entitled to a ryotwari patta in respect of a all ryoti lands which, immediately before the notified date, were properly included or ought to have been properly included in the holding and which are not either lanka lands or lands in respect of which a land-holder or some other person is entitled to a ryotwari patta under any other provision of this Act and

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.11 entitles ryotwari patta only for ryoti lands properly included in holding or lanka lands; suit lands communal, excluded from ryoti land definition under MELA s.3(16).

holdings.text: For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to accept the contention of the appellants that Survey Nos. 16 to 18 have ceased to be communal lands or that the appellants had obtained any lawful title to them.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to accept the contention of the appellants that Survey Nos. 16 to 18 have ceased to be communal lands or that the appellants had obtained any lawful title to them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: no valid conversion under Collector's order, Estates Manager, or ASO patta; lands remain communal.

holdings.text: The controversy with which we, are concerned in this case viz. whether the suit lands continue to be communal lands does not fall within the scope of that section.

anchor.surface_text: The controversy with which we, are concerned in this case viz. whether the suit lands continue to be communal lands does not fall within the scope of that section. Hence we are unable to accept the contention of the appellant that the order made by the Settlement Officer has become final or conclusive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.56 EAA finality limited to disputes on rent arrears or lawful ryot; does not cover whether lands communal.

holdings.text: Hence s. 189 of the Estates Land Act is not attracted to the present case. The dispute with which we are concerned is a civil dispute. Therefore the courts below had jurisdiction to decide the same under s. 9 of the Civil Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: Hence s. 189 of the Estates Land Act is not attracted to the present case. The dispute with which we are concerned is a civil dispute. Therefore the courts below had jurisdiction to decide the same under s. 9 of the Civil Procedure. Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: MELA s.189 bars civil jurisdiction only for specified suits/applications in Schedule Parts A/B; no Part A reliance; Part B item 5 requires s.20-A(1) Collector order, absent here; falls under CPC s.9.

holdings.text: The rights of the community over the suit lands were not created by the principal or any other land- holder. Hence those rights cannot be said to have been abrogated by cl. c of s. 3 of the Estates Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: The rights of the community over the suit lands were not created by the principal or any other land- holder. Hence those rights cannot be said to have been abrogated by cl. c of s. 3 of the Estates Abolition Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: EAA s.3(b) vests estates in Govt free of encumbrances; s.3(c) abrogates only rights created by landholder; communal rights pre-existing, not created by landholder.

holdings.text: No material was placed before the court to show that the South Vallur Zamindari Estate included Survey Nos. 12 to 18. ... Hence the alleged grant by the Zamindar, does not appear to confer on the first appellant any title.

anchor.surface_text: No material was placed before the court to show that the South Vallur Zamindari Estate included Survey Nos. 12 to 18. ... In view of S. 20 and 20-A of the Estates Land Act, to which we shall refer a little later, no Zamindar appears to have had any right to deal with communal lands. Hence the alleged grant by the Zamindar, does not appear to confer on the first appellant any title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof lands in zamindari estate; Zamindar no power to grant communal lands under MELA ss.20,20-A.

holdings.text: Ryoti land means cultivable land in an estate other than private land but does not include ... other lands situated in any estate which are set apart for the common use of the villagers.

anchor.surface_text: Ryoti land is defined in s. 3 16 which says Ryoti land means cultivable land in an estate other than private land but does not include- a b throshing-floor, cattle-stands, village sites, and other lands situated in any estate which are set apart for the common use of the villagers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition excludes communal lands from ryoti land.

precedents.citation: Valathar Mooppannar and ors. v. The Board of Revenue, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: see the decision of the Madras High Court in Valathar Mooppannar and ors. v. The Board of Revenue, Madras 1 . That officer has purported to grant the patta in question even without notice to the interested parties and that during ,the pendency of the suit. For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to accept the contention of the appellants that Survey Nos. 16 to 18 have ceased to be communal lands or that the appellants had obtained any lawful title to them.

precedents.case_name: Valathar Mooppannar v. Board of Revenue, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Assistant Settlement Officer has no competence to grant ryotwari patta in respect of communal lands under Section 11 of the Estates Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: The controversy with which we, are concerned in this case viz. whether the suit lands continue to be communal lands does not fall within the scope of that section. Hence we are unable to accept the contention of the appellant that the order made by the Settlement Officer has become final or conclusive.
In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Hence s. 189 of the Estates Land Act is not attracted to the present case. The dispute with which we are concerned is a civil dispute. Therefore the courts below had jurisdiction to decide the same under s. 9 of the Civil Procedure. Code.

anchor.surface_text: The rights of the community over the suit lands were not created by the principal or any other land- holder. Hence those rights cannot be said to have been abrogated by cl. c of s. 3 of the Estates Abolition Act.
In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with costs.
